channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘60 Minutes’ Airs Apology on Benghazi
item.description: The CBS newsmagazine issued a rare retraction and apology for its report on an attack on Americans in Libya, saying it was misled by a source.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER and BILL CARTER
item.media:description: CBS said it was “a mistake” to broadcast statements by Dylan Davies, a security contractor.

item.title: Vast Challenges for Philippines After Typhoon
item.description: Typhoon Haiyan delivered a crippling blow to the country’s midsection and appeared to have brought a heavy loss of life to cities, towns and villages.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: An Iranian Deputy Minister Is Assassinated in Tehran
item.description: An unidentified attacker shot and killed a deputy minister of industry on Sunday, in the first reported assassination of a senior national official in Iran in years.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Venezuelan Soldiers Deployed to Stores
item.description: The socialist government dispatched soldiers to a major chain of electronic goods stores, ordering prices slashed there and in other shops it has accused of gouging.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Shoppers crowded an electronics store in Caracas, where the president ordered prices slashed.

item.title: Iran Balked at Language of Draft Nuclear Deal, Western Diplomats Say
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said that despite concerns from Israel and others, the nuclear limits he was seeking for Iran would be strong and would serve Israel’s interest.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: The European Union foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran in Geneva.

item.title: Danger Persists for Reporters in Pakistan, Despite Vow to Protect Them
item.description: Five journalists have died so far this year in Pakistan, and by some accounts, the dangers of reporting in the nation have been intensifying.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Removing Fuel Rods Poses New Risks at Crippled Nuclear Plant in Japan
item.description: A plan to move radioactive fuel to safer storage at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant is a critical step in a long decommissioning process that has already had serious setbacks.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Members of the media inside the Fukushima Daiichi plant on Thursday. The plant’s operator plans to start moving radioactive fuel to safer storage.

item.title: Salvador Journal: A Brazilian Boom Town of ‘Eternal Beauty’ Faces Its Dark Side
item.description: Salvador has experienced a surge in violent crime, chaotic traffic, and the metamorphosis of once-elegant seaside districts into crime-ridden areas.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of Gilson Barreto, a doorman who was shot dead in 2008 by the police.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: No Quick Fixes for China’s Overwhelmed Organ Transplant System
item.description: China has vowed to end its reliance on executions for transplant organs, but public distrust has slowed development of a donation system.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A medical worker holds a cornea taken from an organ donor at a hospital in Wuhan, Hubei Province.

item.title: After Clashes With Saudis, Laborers Opt to Go Home
item.description: Thousands of foreign laborers turned themselves over to the Saudi authorities after protests on Saturday over a Saudi campaign against illegal immigrants led to the deaths of two people.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Saudi security forces detain Ethiopian workers during a riot in Manfouha in southern Riyadh, on Saturday.

item.title: Service Sector Gaining Steam in Chinese Economy
item.description: As China’s policy makers gather in Beijing this week to discuss how to overhaul the economy, signs abound that the service sector is playing an increasingly important role.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Li Ning, a sports retailer, has thousands of stores around the country.

item.title: The Lede: Aerial Views of Devastation in the Philippines
item.description: For the first time since Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, aerial views are showing the extent of the damage in some parts of the country, cut off because of downed communication lines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Leaving the Land: New China Cities: Shoddy Homes, Broken Hope
item.description: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Pressure Mounts to Return Nazi-Looted Art
item.description: As more reports emerged about a German art dealer’s shady business with the Nazis, there were calls for the authorities to do more to return lost artworks to their rightful owners.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Maldives Court Orders Another Delay After Presidential Vote Sets Up Runoff
item.description: Former President Mohamed Nasheed won the most votes but did not break the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid a second round.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A woman cast her vote on Saturday in Male, Maldives. If no candidate receives 50 percent of the votes, a runoff will be held on Sunday.

item.title: Venezuela Releases U.S. Journalist After 2 Days
item.description: Venezuelan officials released Jim Wyss, a bureau chief for The Miami Herald, after he was detained Thursday near the Colombian border.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Storied Party of Mandela Faces South Africa Unrest
item.description: Twenty years after the African National Congress swept to power in apartheid’s wake, discontent with its leaders is creating an opening for a new political party.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Thousands rallied in Marikana last month.

item.title: Conservative U.S. Catholics Feel Left Out of the Pope’s Embrace
item.description: Conservative Catholics say Pope Francis’ recent comments about abortion and gay marriage are muddying doctrine to appeal to the broadest possible audience.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: Elderly Woman’s Killing Lays Bare Myanmar’s Religious Divisions
item.description: The stabbing death of a helpless 94-year-old woman is a stark symbol of the breadth of anti-Muslim feelings in a Buddhist-majority country.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: David Hogsholt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The daughter of Daw Aye Kyi, a partly paralyzed 94-year-old woman who was stabbed to death in the village of Thabyu Chaing.

item.title: Aided by Army of ‘Vapers,’ E-Cigarette Industry Woos and Wins Europe
item.description: Eluding restrictions, e-cigarette sellers outgunned not just the tobacco companies but also pharmaceutical companies that make competing products for people trying to stop smoking.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: An electronic cigarette seller in London smoked one of his products. The European Parliament decided last month not to restrict e-cigarettes.

item.title: Talks With Iran Fail to Produce a Nuclear Agreement
item.description: Puncturing days of feverish anticipation, marathon talks were stymied not only by divisions between Iran and major powers, but also by fissures within the group negotiating with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: “The Geneva meeting allowed us to advance, but we were not able to conclude because there are still some questions to be addressed,” the French foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, said.

item.title: Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required)
item.description: When the president travels and needs to handle sensitive information, he ducks into a security tent set up by aides to shield himself from secret cameras and listening devices.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: President Obama discussing Libya inside his security tent during a trip to Rio de Janeiro in 2011.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Said to Recapture Base
item.description: Syrian rebels recaptured a base near the international airport in the northern city of Aleppo in a counteroffensive hours after the Syrian Army had advanced into the area, activists said on Saturday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Philippine Typhoon Death Toll Feared in Thousands
item.description: One of the strongest storms ever to make landfall cut a path of destruction through several islands, leading to early, unconfirmed estimates of as many as 10,000 dead.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Manfred Rommel, Son of German Field Marshal, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Rommel, a three-term mayor of Stuttgart, was a liberal voice in postwar West Germany, supporting immigrant rights and strengthening the city’s Jewish population.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
